In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

```
function wrap_string(str, text_width::Int = 10)
    lines = []
    for word in split(str, " ")
        if length(word) + 1 > text_width
            push!(lines, "")
        end
        push!(lines, word)
    end
    return join(lines, "\n")
end
```
This function takes a string `str` and an optional parameter `text_width`, which specifies the maximum width of the string. If not specified, it defaults to 10. The function splits the input string into words using the `split` function and iterates over them. For each word, it checks if the length of the current line plus the length of the current word exceeds the `text_width`. If it does, a new line is created by pushing an empty string to the `lines` array. The word is then pushed to the same array. Once all words have been processed, the lines are joined using the `join` function and returned as a single string.

Example usage:
```
julia> wrap_string("This is a sample text that needs to be wrapped", 10)
"This is a\nsample text\nthat needs\nto be wrapped"
```
In this example, the input string "This is a sample text that needs to be wrapped" is split into words and then wrapped at a maximum width of 10 characters. The resulting lines are joined using newlines and returned as a single string.
